docs.title: Part III – Finding, Reading, and Tracking Research
docs.text: “Great researchers aren’t just great writers—they’re great readers. They know what to look for, how to read it, and where to keep it.”

docs.title: 📚 From Search to Synthesis
docs.text:
At this point, you’ve chosen your research direction and learned how to navigate the academic landscape. Now it’s time to dig into the literature itself.

This is where your research journey becomes hands-on. The ability to find, read, and organize papers is what separates a struggling student from a confident, capable researcher. It’s not just about collecting information—it’s about building understanding and insight.

But here’s where many students get stuck: - You download dozens of PDFs but don’t actually read them. - You highlight everything—and remember nothing. - You lose track of which paper said what. - You feel burned out before you even start writing.

These are common pitfalls, and they can derail your progress if you don’t have a system. The good news is that with the right strategies, you can avoid information overload and make your reading time truly productive.

Part III is your antidote to all of that.

This section teaches you how to find, read, and organize academic papers in a way that saves time and sets you up for success when writing your thesis or related work section.

You’ll learn to approach the literature with purpose, using proven techniques to extract what matters and keep your research organized from day one.

docs.title: What You’ll Master in This Part
docs.text:
• Where to search for credible, high-impact research papers
  • How to read a paper efficiently—skimming, deep diving, and synthesizing
  • How to take useful notes, avoid PDF hoarding, and reduce burnout
  • How to use tools like Zotero, Obsidian, Notion, or spreadsheets to track your research
  • How to build a “literature matrix” that makes your related work section 10x easier

You’ll also develop habits that will serve you throughout your academic and professional life, making you a more effective reader, writer, and thinker.

docs.title: Why This Part Matters
docs.text:
You can’t write good research without reading good research. But reading papers blindly is inefficient—and overwhelming.

The most successful researchers are those who read strategically, organize their knowledge, and know how to retrieve what they’ve learned when it’s time to write.

This part will help you:

  • Build a reliable system for sourcing and organizing academic work
  • Read deeply without burning out
  • Capture what matters instead of drowning in details

By mastering these skills, you’ll transform reading from a chore into a source of inspiration and clarity.

When it’s time to write, you’ll be able to say: “I’ve already mapped the landscape. Now I know where my contribution fits.”

Take your time with this part. The investment you make here will pay off every time you sit down to write, present, or discuss your research.

docs.text: “You can’t contribute to a field you don’t understand. Before you build your thesis, learn the terrain of where ideas live, get published, and get cited.”

docs.title: 🌐 Understanding the World You're Entering
docs.text:
Once you've chosen your direction, you might feel tempted to dive straight into coding or writing.

It's natural to want to start building immediately. But effective research requires context—understanding what's been done, where the conversations are happening, and how knowledge flows through the academic community.

But research isn't just about building something new—it's about building on what's already been done. And to do that, you need to understand the ecosystem of academic research: Where is knowledge stored? How is it shared? What makes some papers more important or trusted than others?

The academic world has its own infrastructure, norms, and hierarchies. Learning to navigate this landscape will help you find the right sources, avoid wasting time on low-quality work, and position your own research effectively.

This part of the handbook will teach you to read the map before making your mark.

Think of this as learning the rules of the game. Once you understand how research is published, shared, and evaluated, you'll be able to participate with confidence and strategy.

  • Where and how to find papers that actually matter for your field

You'll develop a researcher's eye for quality and relevance, learning to distinguish between influential work and noise.

Without a clear understanding of the research landscape, you risk building on shaky foundations or missing important work that could inform your approach.

This part will help you:

Bottom line: If your research journey is a hike, this part is your map and compass. By the end of Part II, you won't just be consuming research—you'll know how to navigate it.

Invest time in understanding the landscape now, and you'll save yourself countless hours of confusion and frustration later.

docs.title: Part IV – Academic Integrity & Writing With Impact
docs.text: “Great research isn’t just about what you discover—it’s about how ethically and clearly you communicate it.”

docs.title: ✍️ From Ideas to Trustworthy Writing
docs.text:
Reading and collecting research is only half the battle. At some point, you’ll need to start writing—and when you do, questions will start to pile up:

Writing is where your research becomes visible to the world. It’s also where your credibility is built—or lost. The transition from reading to writing can be daunting, but it’s also an opportunity to clarify your thinking and make your contribution count.

  • How much can I copy from the abstract if I cite it?
  • What even counts as plagiarism in research?
  • How do I cite 30+ papers without going insane?
  • How do I actually write a good Related Work section?

This part of the handbook tackles the often-overlooked side of research writing: Academic integrity, citation practices, and clear, ethical communication.

You’ll learn not just how to avoid mistakes, but how to write with confidence, clarity, and respect for the work of others.

docs.title: What You’ll Master in This Part
docs.text:
• What counts as plagiarism (and how to avoid it in subtle cases like self-plagiarism and paraphrasing)
  • The rules of proper citation (APA, IEEE, BibTeX, Zotero, etc.)
  • How to write a well-organized Related Work section using your notes and literature matrix
  • How to build credibility through writing style, clarity, and proper attribution

You’ll also develop habits that will serve you in every future writing project, academic or professional.

docs.title: Why This Part Matters
docs.text:
Even excellent technical work can get rejected—or worse, retracted—if it lacks academic integrity.

Academic writing is about more than just avoiding trouble. It’s about building a reputation for honesty, rigor, and thoughtfulness. Reviewers and readers are more likely to trust and engage with your work if it’s presented ethically and clearly.

But beyond avoiding mistakes, this part helps you:

  • Write more clearly and credibly
  • Build trust with reviewers
  • Position your research within the broader conversation
  • Show that you’ve done your homework—and that your work builds meaningfully on what came before

By mastering these skills, you’ll set yourself apart as a researcher who not only discovers new knowledge, but communicates it responsibly.

Bottom line: Your ideas deserve to be heard—but they also need to be respected. This part will show you how to write in a way that’s both ethical and effective.

Take your time with this part. The habits you build here will shape your reputation and impact for years to come.

docs.title: From Overwhelm to Focus
docs.text:
Every new researcher faces a moment of disorientation.

It’s normal to feel lost at the beginning. The world of research is vast, and the pressure to “find your niche” can be paralyzing. You might worry about making the wrong choice, or feel like everyone else already has a plan. The truth is, most researchers start with uncertainty—and that’s not a weakness, but a starting point.

You're told to “do research,” but nobody tells you how to pick a topic, what counts as a contribution, or even which problems are worth solving. Your head spins with buzzwords—AI, blockchain, cybersecurity, NLP, cloud, HCI—and somehow, you're supposed to pick one and go deep?

You may find yourself jumping from one buzzword to another, feeling pressure to chase trends or impress others. But real progress comes from understanding your own interests, strengths, and values—and learning how to match them to the research landscape.

This part exists to anchor you before the storm sweeps you away.

These first three chapters help you navigate the early wilderness of research with intention—not by giving you the “correct” topic, but by equipping you with the mental tools to choose your topic well.

You’ll learn to ask better questions, reflect on what excites you, and set realistic expectations for your journey. The goal isn’t to eliminate confusion, but to use it as fuel for exploration.

• The emotional and cognitive chaos of starting research—and how to survive it
  • Different types of computer science research (theoretical, applied, system-level, empirical, etc.)
  • Strategic criteria for narrowing down a thesis topic that’s both feasible and meaningful
  • The difference between passion projects and publishable research—and where they can overlap

You’ll also gain practical strategies for moving from vague curiosity to actionable research questions, and for balancing ambition with feasibility.

docs.title: Why This Part Matters
docs.text:
Too many students waste months chasing ideas that are either too vague, too ambitious, or disconnected from their interests.

It’s easy to get caught up in the excitement of new technologies or the fear of missing out. But clarity comes from honest self-assessment and a willingness to explore before committing.

This part is here to prevent that.

By the end of Part I, you’ll be able to:

  • Articulate why you’re pursuing research in the first place
  • Classify and compare different research styles and domains
  • Make a clear, well-reasoned decision about your research direction

You’ll be equipped to move forward with confidence, knowing that your choice is grounded in both self-awareness and a solid understanding of the field.

This clarity is your foundation. Everything else—literature reviews, experiments, papers—will be built on it.

Take your time with this part. The effort you invest here will pay off throughout your research journey.

docs.title: From Draft to Publication
docs.text:
You’ve done the reading. You’ve chosen your topic. You’ve organized your notes, and you’re writing with integrity.

This is the stage where your research becomes part of the broader academic conversation. It’s both exciting and challenging—the culmination of months (or years) of effort, and the beginning of your work’s life in the world.

Now it’s time to do what every researcher eventually must: Turn your work into a polished paper—and submit it for review.

The process can feel daunting, but with the right preparation, you’ll move from draft to submission with confidence. This part of the handbook will walk you through every step, so you’re never left wondering what comes next.

But what does that process look like?

  • How do you structure a research paper?
  • What makes a good abstract or conclusion?
  • Where do you submit?
  • How do you respond to reviewers?
  • What happens after you hit “Submit”?

Part V answers all of these questions and prepares you for the full academic publication lifecycle—from your first draft to your first official paper.

You’ll learn not just the mechanics of writing and submission, but also the mindset and habits that lead to successful publication.

• The common structure and formatting of research papers (IMRaD, ACM/IEEE templates)
  • How to navigate the peer review process, including blind review and rebuttals
  • How to revise and respond to feedback professionally
  • What to expect after submission—deadlines, decisions, and next steps
  • How to manage authorship, acknowledgments, and ethical contribution statements

You’ll also gain insight into the unspoken rules and best practices that experienced researchers use to get their work published and recognized.

docs.text:
Many promising research projects never get published—not because the ideas were bad, but because the process was overwhelming or misunderstood.

Publication is the bridge between your work and the world. Understanding the process ensures your ideas have the impact they deserve.

This part will help you:

  • Structure your writing to meet academic expectations
  • Demystify submission systems like EasyChair or PCS
  • Understand how reviewers think—and how to win their confidence
  • Turn feedback into a stronger, sharper paper

By mastering these steps, you’ll be able to share your research with clarity, professionalism, and pride.

Bottom line: You don’t just want to finish your research—you want to share it. This part shows you how to do that with professionalism, clarity, and confidence.

Take your time with this part. Every submission is a learning experience, and each one brings you closer to becoming a skilled, published researcher.

docs.title: Why This Book Exists
docs.text:
This handbook was born not from authority, but from necessity.

It’s a product of real confusion, trial and error, and the gradual discovery that research is as much about process as it is about results. I wrote this for the student who feels overwhelmed by the academic maze, for the builder who wants to make an impact but doesn’t know where to start, and for anyone who wishes someone had just explained the basics, step by step.

As a new researcher in a Master’s program, I expected guidance on how to “do research.” Instead, I found myself lost in a maze of unfamiliar terms—journals, conferences, venues, citations, impact factors—without a map, compass, or even a starting point. No one taught us how to find actual research papers. Or how to tell if something was peer-reviewed. Or how to explore what others have already built in our chosen topic.

The academic world can feel like it’s full of hidden rules and unspoken expectations. I remember the frustration of searching for a single credible paper, the anxiety of not knowing if my sources were legitimate, and the embarrassment of asking “basic” questions that everyone else seemed to already know. If you’ve felt this way, you’re not alone.

I didn’t know what I didn’t know. And that’s the most dangerous kind of blind spot.

This book is my attempt to shine a light on those blind spots, to make the invisible visible, and to give you the confidence to ask better questions and find better answers.

At the same time, I was wrestling with a bigger question:

“What topic should I pursue for my thesis?”

That question haunted me for months. I cycled through ideas, doubted my choices, and worried about picking the “wrong” path. But every misstep taught me something valuable about the research process—and about myself.

I started where I felt most inspired—drones and computer vision. I imagined autonomous systems, smart agriculture, and embedded AI. I built vision projects. I learned CNNs. But then reality hit: it was expensive, hardware-dependent, and logistically hard to execute without institutional resources. So I humbled myself—and pivoted.

The journey from inspiration to execution is rarely a straight line. It’s full of pivots, setbacks, and unexpected discoveries. What matters is not how quickly you find your topic, but how honestly you engage with the process.

I turned to Natural Language Processing, where everything could be built and tested in software alone. What began as a practical decision became a purpose-driven mission. I created intelligent chatbots. I built multi-modal apps like ScanlyAI. And then, I had my breakthrough moment:

Sometimes, the best direction is the one that emerges from constraints. When resources are limited, creativity flourishes. My shift to NLP wasn’t just about convenience—it was about finding a way to make a real difference with the tools I had.

AI can serve society—not just impress it.

This insight crystallized into two thesis directions:

  • AI-Powered Legal Aid Chatbot – Bringing access to justice closer to everyday Filipinos.
  • AI-Powered Transparency Assistant – Letting citizens query government budgets and audit reports conversationally.

These weren’t just feasible. They were impactful. They didn’t just align with my skills. They aligned with my values.

Impact is what transforms research from an academic exercise into a meaningful pursuit. When your work aligns with your values, motivation follows naturally—even when the work gets hard.

So this book is more than a set of academic tips. It’s both: - A map for navigating the research ecosystem (when no one teaches you how). - And a record of what it means to evolve—from vague interest to focused impact.

You’ll find practical advice, hard-won lessons, and encouragement to keep going when things get messy. My hope is that this book will be the companion I wish I’d had—a guide, a reference, and a source of reassurance.

If you’ve ever felt lost choosing a topic, confused by academic structures, or frustrated with the lack of guidance, this handbook is for you.

You don’t have to have it all figured out. You just have to start.

docs.title: Who Should Read This
docs.text:
This handbook is for:

It’s written for anyone who wants to do research with purpose, clarity, and confidence—regardless of background or prior experience.

  • Graduate students—especially those in technical or interdisciplinary programs who feel like they were thrown into the deep end without learning how to swim.
  • Early-stage researchers trying to explore literature, validate their problem space, and understand what has already been done.
  • Self-taught builders transitioning into the academic world of conferences, journals, and research ethics.
  • Professionals writing a thesis after years of software development, seeking clarity without getting buried in jargon.

You don’t need a PhD mindset to use this guide. But you do need a beginner’s curiosity and a builder’s determination.

Bring your questions, your doubts, and your ambition. This book is designed to meet you where you are and help you move forward, one step at a time.

docs.title: From Chaos to Clarity: How This Book Was Born
docs.text:
The turning point came when I realized:

“I cannot finalize my methodology without first understanding what’s already been tried.”

That realization changed everything. It shifted my focus from rushing to results to building a foundation of knowledge and context. It taught me that research is a conversation—and that to contribute, you first have to listen.

That single insight reframed everything.

Before I could build my thesis, I had to build context. Before I could design experiments, I had to understand the landscape. Before I could claim novelty, I had to understand what existed.

And yet, no one showed us how to do that.

So I started asking the questions the classroom skipped:

  • Where do I even find papers on my topic?
  • What’s the difference between a journal and a conference paper?
  • How do I know which sources are credible?
  • What tools do real researchers use to track 100+ papers?
  • How do I organize my reading so I don’t get overwhelmed?

Each time I found an answer, I wrote it down. What started as a survival strategy became a growing knowledge base. That base became a table of contents. And now, it’s this book.

This handbook is the product of hundreds of small discoveries, mistakes, and moments of clarity. It’s proof that you can go from confusion to capability, and that every question you ask brings you closer to understanding.

docs.title: What You’ll Learn (and What You Won’t)
docs.text:
You will learn:

The focus is on actionable steps, not abstract theory. You’ll find checklists, templates, and real-world examples to help you apply what you learn immediately.

  • How to choose a research topic that fits your skills, values, and constraints.
  • How to identify credible academic papers in your field.
  • Where to find research papers, datasets, and tools.
  • How to read, organize, and track what you've studied.
  • What publishers, journals, and conferences are most relevant to CS.
  • How to cite, paraphrase, and build your related work ethically.
  • What tools (Zotero, BibTeX, Obsidian, etc.) can drastically improve your workflow.
  • How the academic publishing and peer review process works—from CFP to revision.

You will not find:

  • Generic theory about “what is research” with no practical use.
  • Overly abstract philosophical debates with no application.
  • Fluffy motivational filler about “believing in yourself.”
  • Academic jargon with no clarity.

This is a hands-on, confused-to-capable, read-this-before-your-thesis-falls-apart type of book.

If you’re looking for a practical, no-nonsense guide to surviving and thriving in research, you’re in the right place.

docs.title: How to Read This Handbook

Each section is modular and practical.

You can use this book as a reference, a workbook, or a troubleshooting guide. Return to it whenever you hit a roadblock or need a dose of clarity.

  • Action steps and tools are called out clearly—so you can apply them right away.
  • Appendices include templates, citation guides, and sample materials to copy or adapt.
  • Your topic may change. Your workflow may evolve. That’s the point. This handbook evolves with you.

This is not the book your professor handed out. This is the book I wish someone handed me when I first Googled:

“how to find related papers and write a research proposal in CS.”

docs.title: Chapter 1: The Chaos Before the Focus
docs.text: “You can’t chart your course until you admit you’re lost. Confusion is not the enemy—it’s the beginning.”

docs.title: Why This Chapter Matters
docs.text:
Before you settle on a research topic, you will likely feel confused, overwhelmed, or even directionless. That’s normal.

In fact, that’s necessary.

This initial confusion is not just a rite of passage—it’s a sign that you are engaging with something complex and meaningful. Many students expect to find their path quickly, but the reality is that research is a process of discovery, not a checklist. The uncertainty you feel is shared by even the most experienced researchers, and it is often the spark that leads to genuine insight.

No one tells you how wide, deep, and multidimensional computer science research really is—until you’re dropped right into it. Suddenly you’re faced with dozens of fields, each with their own lingo, legacy papers, tools, and paradigms. Worse, your peers seem to already have it figured out. Spoiler: they don’t.

This chapter exists to normalize the early-stage chaos. To show you that confusion isn’t a sign of incompetence—it’s a signal that you’re about to grow.

We’ll explore how to navigate this early fog by listening to your interests, following curiosity without pressure, and gradually carving a direction that’s meaningful to you.

docs.title: Conceptual Breakdown
docs.text:
🔹 Why Confusion Is the Starting Line It’s tempting to think that research begins with clarity. But in truth, it often begins with uncertainty, curiosity, or even frustration.

You may:

  • Feel like you’re supposed to “have a topic already”
  • Jump between buzzwords (AI, blockchain, HCI) without knowing what they mean
  • Compare yourself to classmates who already chose a path

This confusion is not a barrier—it’s a fertile ground for growth. The process of sifting through ideas, questioning assumptions, and wrestling with ambiguity is what sharpens your thinking. In fact, some of the most innovative research projects began as vague questions or half-formed interests. Embrace this stage as a time to gather inspiration, not to judge your progress.

This stage is part of the journey. The only wrong move is rushing a decision you don’t yet understand.

🔹 How I Got Lost (and Found Direction) Here’s a real story. I started with Computer Vision, pivoted to NLP, then landed on AI for Public Service. Each shift taught me something:

  • Computer Vision showed me what excites me (seeing things work visually)
  • NLP revealed my love for language, structure, and real-world relevance
  • AI for Governance let me anchor tech to a social impact mission

Each transition was marked by uncertainty and a sense of starting over. But with every pivot, I gained new skills, met new mentors, and discovered aspects of research I hadn’t considered before. The journey was not linear, and at times, I doubted my choices. Looking back, those moments of doubt were actually moments of learning. They forced me to reflect on what truly mattered to me, and to seek out communities and resources that aligned with my evolving interests.

You don’t need to commit to your first interest. You just need to start exploring.

🔹 Your Journey Is Not a Straight Line Most great researchers did not “know” their final topic from the beginning. They arrived there by:

  • Reading broadly
  • Trying small experiments
  • Talking to others
  • Listening to what problems made them feel something

It’s important to recognize that research is rarely a solitary pursuit. Collaboration, discussion, and feedback are essential. Don’t hesitate to reach out to professors, attend seminars, or join study groups. Sometimes, a casual conversation can open doors to new fields or clarify your thinking. The path may twist and turn, but every experience adds to your toolkit as a researcher.

Research is not just technical. It’s emotional, reflective, and personal.

🔹 The Inner Questions That Matter Instead of asking:

  • “What’s trending?”
  • “What’s publishable?”
  • “What will impress people?”

Ask:

  • “What problem do I care enough to sit with for months?”
  • “What kinds of papers do I find fascinating—even before I understand them fully?”
  • “What would I be proud to work on, even if it fails?”

These questions are designed to help you dig deeper into your motivations. Take time to journal your thoughts, discuss them with mentors, or even debate them with friends. The answers may not come immediately, but the act of asking is itself a step toward clarity. Remember, authentic research is driven by curiosity and passion, not just external rewards.

These questions don’t give quick answers. But they lead to authentic direction.

docs.title: Self-Check Questions
docs.text:
Use these to reflect on where you are:

  1. What research topics have caught your curiosity, even just a little?
  2. What kinds of problems do you find personally meaningful?
  3. What skills or knowledge do you want to build through research?
  4. Are there fields where you feel a natural sense of “I want to learn more”?
  5. What kinds of impact would you like your work to make?

Take a moment to write down your answers. Don’t worry about getting them “right”—the goal is to start a conversation with yourself. Over time, revisit these questions and see how your responses evolve. This ongoing reflection will help you notice patterns in your interests and values, guiding you toward a research direction that feels authentic.

docs.title: Try This Exercise
docs.text:
Journal Prompt: “If I had unlimited time and no pressure to publish or impress anyone, I would explore __ because ____.”

Write 3 versions of this. You’ll notice a pattern.

As you complete this exercise, pay attention to recurring themes or ideas. These patterns can reveal your underlying interests and motivations. Don’t be afraid to dream big or think outside the box—sometimes the most unconventional ideas lead to the most rewarding research.

docs.title: Builder's Insight
docs.text:
When you’re just starting, you’ll want to chase clarity.

But sometimes, the most honest step forward is to document your confusion. Turn your questions into a map. Turn your uncertainty into exploration.

Direction comes not from knowing everything, but from choosing something and walking with curiosity.

Remember, every researcher starts somewhere. The willingness to embrace confusion, ask questions, and pursue curiosity is what sets successful researchers apart. Treat this chapter as your invitation to begin—not with certainty, but with openness and a sense of adventure. Your journey is uniquely yours, and every step you take brings you closer to finding your focus.

docs.title: Chapter 10: Academic Integrity 101
docs.text: “In research, your name travels with your work. What you publish is not just yours—it’s your reputation.”

docs.title: Why This Chapter Matters
docs.text:
Academic research is built on trust—trust that your ideas are yours, your citations are accurate, and your results are real.

Integrity is the foundation of the academic community. Every paper you read, cite, or publish is part of a larger conversation built on honesty and respect. Violating these principles can have serious consequences—not just for your reputation, but for your career and the credibility of your field.

But when you're new to research, it’s easy to cross a line without realizing it. Maybe you reused part of a school paper. Maybe you paraphrased a paper too closely. Maybe you submitted the same draft to two venues without knowing the rules.

This chapter is here to make those boundaries crystal clear—so you can protect your work, your credibility, and your future opportunities.

By understanding the rules and best practices of academic integrity, you’ll avoid common pitfalls and set yourself up for long-term success. Transparency and respect for others’ work are not just formalities—they are essential habits for every researcher.

docs.title: Conceptual Breakdown
docs.text:
🔹 What Is Academic Integrity in Research?

It means:

Academic integrity is more than just avoiding plagiarism. It’s about being honest in every aspect of your research: how you collect data, how you analyze results, and how you present your findings. It also means respecting the work of others and contributing to a culture of trust.

  • Giving proper credit to the ideas, words, and results of others
  • Being honest about what is new, reused, or replicated
  • Following the submission and review rules of each journal or conference
  • Reporting your methods, data, and results transparently

Academic misconduct isn't always malicious. But ignorance is not an excuse.

If you’re ever unsure about what’s allowed, ask your advisor or check your institution’s guidelines. It’s always better to clarify than to risk a mistake.

🔹 Plagiarism: The Obvious and the Subtle

Type What It Looks Like Direct plagiarism Copy-pasting sentences or paragraphs without citation Paraphrasing plagiarism Rewriting someone’s ideas without giving credit Self-plagiarism Reusing your own previous work without disclosure Source misrepresentation Citing a paper without actually using or understanding it

Plagiarism can be accidental or intentional, but the consequences are the same. Always keep careful notes on your sources and double-check your citations before submitting any work.

✅ Rule of thumb: If the idea, method, or phrasing is not yours—cite it.

When in doubt, cite. It’s better to have too many citations than too few.

🔹 What is Self-Plagiarism?

This surprises many students. If you wrote something before—can’t you reuse it?

Not always.

Self-plagiarism is often misunderstood. Even if you are the original author, reusing your own work without disclosure can mislead readers and reviewers. Always be transparent about what is new and what is reused.

You must disclose when:

  • Reusing paragraphs from a prior class paper
  • Submitting the same work to two journals/conferences
  • Publishing multiple papers using the same dataset or results

📌 Journals and conferences expect original work, not recycled drafts.

If you want to build on your previous work, explain how the new paper extends or differs from the old one. Most venues allow this with proper disclosure.

🔹 Double Submissions and Duplicate Publications

Most venues follow a strict rule:

“Do not submit your paper to more than one venue at the same time.”

Submitting the same work to multiple venues is considered unethical because it wastes the time of editors and reviewers. It can also create confusion about who has the right to publish your work.

Why?

  • It wastes reviewer time
  • It creates confusion over publication rights
  • It can get you banned from submitting in the future

Some exceptions exist (e.g., a workshop version → journal version), but always disclose.

If you’re unsure whether your submission counts as a duplicate, ask the editors or your advisor before proceeding.

🔹 Publisher Policies: ACM and IEEE Examples

Publisher Key Policy Highlights ACM Requires originality, prohibits duplicate submissions, investigates plagiarism IEEE Strict on self-plagiarism, uses plagiarism-detection software, may retract papers

Most major publishers have clear, public policies on academic integrity. Familiarize yourself with these before submitting your work. Violations can result in retraction, bans, or even legal action.

✅ Visit the publisher’s website and read their Author Ethics page before submitting.

Many publishers also provide resources and checklists to help you avoid common mistakes. Take advantage of these tools.

docs.title: Self-Check Questions
docs.text:
1. Are you citing ideas—even if you’re not quoting them directly?
  2. Are you reusing any material from your previous work? If yes, are you disclosing it?
  3. Have you read the submission policy of your target venue?

Reflect on your current practices and identify any areas where you could be more transparent or careful. Academic integrity is a habit, not a one-time action.

docs.title: Try This Exercise
docs.text:
Integrity Audit Prompt Choose one of your current or past writing drafts. Ask:

  • Did I copy or closely paraphrase any source?
  • Did I cite every paper I used—even if indirectly?
  • Am I planning to submit this to multiple venues?
  • Have I reused results, graphs, or methods from another project?

If you find any issues, address them before submitting your work. It’s always better to correct mistakes early than to deal with consequences later.

If yes to any of these, write a disclosure note and ask your advisor what’s acceptable in your case.

Open communication with your advisor or collaborators is key. They can help you navigate tricky situations and ensure your work meets the highest standards.

docs.title: Researcher’s Compass
docs.text:
You can build a strong academic reputation from your first paper onward—if you lead with transparency and respect.

Academic integrity is a lifelong commitment. The habits you build now will serve you throughout your career, whether you stay in academia or move into industry.

  • Don’t underestimate how seriously journals and universities treat misconduct.
  • Don’t fear citations—they build your credibility, not weaken it.
  • And don’t hesitate to ask when you’re unsure.

Integrity is not just about rules. It’s about honoring the work of others while building your own.

Lead by example, and you’ll earn the trust and respect of your peers, mentors, and the broader research community.

docs.title: Chapter 11: Citing and Referencing
docs.text: “Every citation is a signal: I’ve done the work, I’ve read the field, and I know where my ideas fit.”

docs.title: Why This Chapter Matters
docs.text:
Citation isn’t just about avoiding plagiarism. It’s how you enter the conversation of research.

Proper citation is a mark of professionalism and respect. It shows that you’ve done your homework, that you value the contributions of others, and that you’re committed to building knowledge collaboratively. Mastering citation practices will make your writing stronger and your research more credible.

Citations show that:

  • You’re building on credible, peer-reviewed work
  • You understand the state of the art
  • You know which ideas are yours—and which came from others

This chapter will help you cite responsibly, format correctly, and stay organized—so that your thesis, research papers, and presentations are all built on a strong foundation of attribution.

You’ll also learn how to streamline your workflow, avoid common mistakes, and use tools that make managing references much easier.

docs.title: Conceptual Breakdown
docs.text:
🔹 What to Cite (and When)

You should cite when:

Citation is about transparency. If a reader could reasonably wonder where an idea, method, or result came from, you should provide a reference. This helps others trace your intellectual path and builds trust in your work.

  • An idea, method, result, or dataset comes from another paper
  • You paraphrase or summarize someone’s work
  • You reuse figures, tables, or even experimental setup
  • You're inspired by a framework, tool, or model implementation

💡 You don’t need to cite common knowledge (e.g., “deep learning models use backpropagation”).

When in doubt, ask your advisor or check published papers in your field to see what’s considered common knowledge.

🔹 Common Citation Formats in CS

Format Common In Looks Like IEEE Engineering, CS, AI conferences [1] J. Smith, “Title,” IEEE Trans. on X, 2020. ACM ACM conferences, SIG venues [Smith 2020] APA Interdisciplinary, HCI, social science Smith, J. (2020). Title. Journal Name.

Each format has its own rules for author order, punctuation, and abbreviations. Always use the template or style file provided by your target venue to avoid formatting errors.

📌 Always check your target venue’s template and formatting rules. They usually provide .cls or .bst files for LaTeX.

If you’re using Word, citation plugins can help you switch between formats as needed. For LaTeX users, BibTeX and BibLaTeX are essential tools.

🔹 Tools to Manage Your References

Tool What It Does Zotero Collect, organize, tag, and cite references; integrates with Word/LibreOffice Mendeley Similar to Zotero, stronger PDF annotation features BibTeX Plaintext reference format for LaTeX documents Overleaf Online LaTeX editor with built-in BibTeX integration

Choose a tool that fits your workflow and writing environment. Many researchers use a combination (e.g., Zotero for collection, BibTeX for LaTeX writing). Explore plugins and integrations to make your process seamless.

✅ Pro Tip: Use Zotero + BibTeX for the best of both worlds: visual management and LaTeX compatibility.

Regularly back up your reference library and keep it organized with folders or tags by topic, project, or paper section.

🔹 How to Generate a .bib File (for LaTeX Users)

  1. Add your papers to Zotero
  2. Select the papers → Right click → Export as BibTeX
  3. Save as refs.bib
  4. In your .tex file:

```latex \bibliographystyle{IEEEtran} \bibliography{refs} ````

Check your exported .bib file for errors or missing fields. Sometimes, imported entries from Google Scholar or other sources need manual cleanup.

🎯 You can also use Google Scholar to export BibTeX entries—but double-check for formatting errors.

If you’re collaborating, share your .bib file or use a shared reference manager to keep everyone on the same page.

🔹 Citing Code and Tools

When using open-source projects, APIs, or models:

Citing software and datasets is increasingly important in CS research. Many projects now provide a preferred citation format—use it whenever possible. If not, cite the original paper or describe the tool clearly in your methods section.

  • Look for a CITATION.txt file in the GitHub repo
  • If none, cite the original paper associated with the tool (e.g., “Transformers” → cite the BERT or HuggingFace paper)

⚠️ Don’t cite GitHub URLs without context. Always include author, year, title, and version if possible.

Properly citing code and tools helps others reproduce your work and gives credit to developers who support the research community.

docs.title: Self-Check Questions
docs.text:
1. Are you using a reference manager (Zotero, Mendeley, or BibTeX)?
  2. Do you know your target venue’s citation format?
  3. Have you double-checked for missing or incorrect citations in your drafts?

Take time to review your references before submitting any paper. Incomplete or incorrect citations can delay publication or weaken your credibility.

docs.title: Try This Exercise
docs.text:
Build Your Citation Workflow

  1. Install Zotero + browser connector
  2. Add 5 papers you’ve read this week
  3. Tag each by topic (e.g., #LLM, #legalNLP, #transformers)
  4. Export to BibTeX and integrate into an Overleaf project

As you practice this workflow, you’ll find it easier to keep your references organized and ready for any writing project.

You now have a clean, searchable citation workflow—and a .bib file ready for use.

Update your reference library regularly and use tags or folders to keep track of sources for different sections of your thesis or papers.

docs.title: Researcher’s Compass
docs.text:
Citing is more than just “giving credit.”

It’s also a way to map the intellectual landscape of your field. Well-chosen citations show that you understand the context of your work and can guide readers to further information.

It’s how you build trust. It’s how you acknowledge the community. And it’s how you show that your work belongs in the field.

A well-cited paper says: I know where I stand—and I know whose shoulders I’m standing on.

Make citation a habit, not an afterthought. Your future self—and your readers—will thank you.

docs.title: Chapter 12: Writing the Related Work Section
docs.text: “You don’t just cite papers to check a box. You cite to tell a story—where your work fits, what it adds, and what it challenges.”

docs.title: Why This Chapter Matters
docs.text:
You’ve read the papers. You’ve taken the notes. Now comes the hard part: turning all of that into a coherent Related Work section.

The Related Work section is your chance to demonstrate your understanding of the field and to position your research within it. A well-crafted narrative not only shows that you’ve done your homework, but also helps reviewers and readers see the value and originality of your work. This section can make the difference between a paper that gets accepted and one that gets overlooked.

This section is more than a list of citations—it’s a narrative. A map. A justification for why your research matters. And if it’s well written, it can convince reviewers and advisors that your work is thoughtful, original, and grounded.

Think of this section as the bridge between what’s been done and what you are about to do. It’s where you show that you’re not reinventing the wheel, but building on a solid foundation—and that you know exactly where your work fits.

But many students fall into common traps:

  • Writing summaries with no connection
  • Listing papers without analysis
  • Forgetting to explain how their own work is different

Avoiding these traps will help you write a section that is both informative and persuasive. Remember, your goal is to synthesize, not just summarize.

This chapter will help you turn your research reading into a structured, compelling Related Work section.

docs.title: Conceptual Breakdown
docs.text:
🔹 What is the Purpose of a Related Work Section?

  • To situate your work in the context of existing research
  • To show you understand the state of the art
  • To identify gaps or limitations in current work
  • To justify why your approach is needed

This section is also a place to acknowledge the contributions of others and to show that you are aware of ongoing debates, challenges, and open questions in your field.

✍️ Think of it as answering this question: “What have others done—and what’s still missing?”

Your answer to this question should lead directly to your research question or hypothesis.

🔹 From Notes to Narrative: How to Start

You already have structured notes (see Chapter 8) and possibly a literature matrix (see Chapter 9).

Don’t be afraid to revise your groups as you read more papers or as your understanding deepens. The structure of your Related Work section should serve your argument, not the other way around.

Now, follow this process:

  1. Group your papers by theme, method, or problem
  2. Example: “Rule-based approaches,” “Transformer-based models,” “Philippine legal NLP”
  3. Summarize trends and insights per group
  4. What’s been tried? What worked? What didn’t?
  5. Position your work at the end of each group
  6. “Unlike prior work that focused on X, our method explores Y…”

This approach helps you build a logical flow and makes it easy for readers to see how your work advances the field.

🔹 Thematic vs. Chronological Structure

Structure When to Use It Thematic Most common; groups papers by topic or method Chronological Useful when showing the evolution of a technique Hybrid For complex topics with both method and time aspects

Choose the structure that best highlights the novelty and relevance of your work. Thematic organization is usually preferred, but don’t hesitate to use a hybrid approach if it clarifies your argument.

🧠 Reviewers prefer thematic unless time-based progression is essential to your contribution.

Check recent papers in your target venue to see which structure is most common.

🔹 How Many Citations Are Enough?

There’s no perfect number—but aim for depth, not volume.

Focus on citing the most relevant and influential works. Too many citations can dilute your message, while too few can make your work seem disconnected from the field.

  • For a thesis: ~30–60 focused citations across multiple sections
  • For a short paper: ~10–20 highly relevant works
  • Always prioritize quality over quantity

❌ Don’t cite papers you haven’t read ✅ Don’t cite just because they’re popular

Every citation should serve a purpose—either to support your claims, highlight a gap, or contrast with your approach.

🔹 What to Say (and What Not To)

Do:

Use comparison and critique to show your understanding. Explain not just what others did, but why it matters and how it relates to your work.

  • Compare and contrast works (not just describe them)
  • Show how your approach builds on or deviates from others
  • Acknowledge overlaps and shared challenges

Don’t:

Avoid vague praise or generic statements. Be specific about strengths, weaknesses, and how your work addresses open questions.

  • List papers like a bibliography dump
  • Praise every method without critique
  • Forget to say how your work is new

docs.title: Self-Check Questions
docs.text:
1. Have you grouped the papers thematically (or by methodology, domain, etc.)?
  2. Are you clearly stating how your work differs or improves upon existing ones?
  3. Does your narrative build toward the need for your research?

Reflect on your draft and ask a peer or advisor for feedback. A fresh perspective can help you spot gaps or unclear arguments.

docs.title: Try This Exercise
docs.text:
Related Work Builder Prompt Choose one research theme (e.g., transformer-based models for legal text). For each key paper:

  • What problem did they solve?
  • What method did they use?
  • What limitation did they encounter?
  • How does your work address or extend this?

This exercise will help you move from isolated notes to a connected narrative. As you write, look for ways to link papers together and to your own research question.

Now write a 2–3 sentence comparison per paper. String them together—this is your first draft.

Revise your draft for clarity, flow, and logical progression. Make sure each paragraph leads naturally to the next and builds your case for why your work is needed.

docs.title: Researcher’s Compass
docs.text:
The Related Work section is your opportunity to frame the conversation—to show that your research doesn’t exist in a vacuum.

A strong Related Work section demonstrates your expertise and helps reviewers trust your judgment. It also provides a roadmap for future researchers who want to build on your work.

Instead, it stands on top of, next to, or even in contrast to the work of others.

Tell the story of where research has been. Then show why your contribution is the next step forward.

Let your Related Work section be both a map and a springboard—showing where the field has been and where you are taking it next.

docs.title: Chapter 13: Writing Your First Research Paper
docs.text: “A great paper doesn’t just report results—it tells a clear, credible story of discovery.”

docs.title: Why This Chapter Matters
docs.text:
Writing your first research paper is intimidating. There’s the structure, the formatting, the references, the figures—and the invisible voice in your head whispering: “Am I doing this right?”

The process can feel overwhelming, but every published researcher started exactly where you are now. The key is to break the task into manageable steps and to remember that writing is a skill you build with practice. Each draft brings you closer to clarity and confidence.

This chapter is here to quiet that voice.

By following proven structures and strategies, you’ll learn to communicate your ideas effectively and make your research stand out.

We’ll walk you through the anatomy of a research paper, explain what goes where (and why), and show you how to go from raw notes and experiments to a polished, submission-ready manuscript.

You’ll also pick up habits that will serve you well in future writing projects, from theses to journal articles.

docs.title: Conceptual Breakdown
docs.text:
🔹 The IMRaD Structure: Your Default Template

Most computer science research papers follow this core format:

IMRaD stands for Introduction, Methodology, Results, and Discussion/Conclusion. This structure helps readers quickly find the information they need and ensures your argument flows logically from problem to solution.

Section Purpose Introduction State the problem, why it matters, and your core contribution Methodology Explain what you did, how, and why you did it that way Results Present your findings with tables, charts, and comparisons Discussion/Conclusion Reflect on what your results mean, limitations, future work

Some papers also include a Related Work section (usually near the intro) and an Abstract at the very beginning.

Check your target venue’s guidelines for required sections and order. Some venues may combine or rename sections, so always adapt as needed.

📌 Tip: Read 2–3 papers from your target venue and mimic their structure closely.

Pay attention to how successful papers use figures, tables, and references to support their arguments.

🔹 What Goes Into Each Section?

docs.title: Abstract
docs.text:
• A summary of your entire paper in ~150–250 words
  • Should answer: What problem? What method? What result? Why it matters?

Write the abstract last, but keep notes as you go. A strong abstract is concise, specific, and highlights your main contribution.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
• Hook the reader: Why is this problem important?
  • Define the gap in prior work
  • State your objective and main contribution clearly

Use the introduction to set the stage for your research. Make it clear why your work matters and what makes it different from previous efforts.

docs.title: Related Work
docs.text:
• Summarize key prior studies and how your work builds upon or differs from them
  • Use citations strategically to position your work

Organize this section thematically or by method, and always explain how your work fits into or advances the field.

docs.title: Methodology
docs.text:
• Describe your approach, system design, dataset, experimental setup
  • Be clear enough that someone could reproduce your work

Include enough detail for others to replicate your results. Use diagrams or pseudocode if it helps clarify your process.

docs.title: Results
docs.text:
• Show your findings with tables, graphs, metrics
  • Compare against baselines or prior work when possible

Highlight the most important findings and explain what they mean. Use visuals to make your results easy to interpret.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
• Restate what you achieved
  • Mention limitations and suggest future work
  • End with a strong takeaway message

The conclusion should leave readers with a clear sense of your contribution and its significance. Suggest next steps or open questions for future research.

🔹 Common Formatting Styles: ACM and IEEE

Most CS venues will ask you to submit in a specific format.

Formatting is not just about aesthetics—it ensures your paper meets professional standards and is easy for reviewers to read. Using the official template from the start saves time and reduces errors.

Format Where It's Used Tools Available IEEE Engineering and many AI conferences LaTeX template, Word template on IEEE author center ACM SIG conferences (CHI, SIGIR, SIGCOMM, etc.) ACM Primary Article Template (Word + LaTeX)

✅ Always start with the official template of your target venue. Never try to format from scratch.

If you’re new to LaTeX or Word templates, look for online tutorials or ask peers for help. Many venues provide sample papers to guide you.

🔹 Helpful Writing Tips for Beginners

  • Use active voice where possible

    e.g., “We trained a CNN model…” instead of “A CNN model was trained…”

  • Keep sentences short and precise

  • Use section headers to break up the narrative
  • Start writing before your experiments are done—write in parallel
  • Don’t wait for the “perfect phrasing” on first draft—just write

Don’t be afraid to revise and rewrite. Good writing is the result of multiple drafts and feedback from others. Share your work with peers or mentors for constructive criticism.

📌 Writing is revising. Your first draft isn’t final—it’s a map to the final.

Set small, achievable writing goals and celebrate your progress. Every paragraph brings you closer to a finished paper.

docs.title: Self-Check Questions
docs.text:
1. Have you read 2–3 recent papers from your target venue to mirror structure and style?
  2. Do you have a clear research contribution you can articulate in 1–2 sentences?
  3. Have you started drafting your Abstract and Introduction—even before results are finalized?

Reflect on these questions as you write. They’ll help you stay focused and ensure your paper is on track.

docs.title: Try This Exercise
docs.text:
Paper Skeleton Starter Open a new doc or Overleaf project and create the section headers:

  • Abstract
    1. Introduction
    1. Related Work
    1. Methodology
    1. Results
    1. Conclusion and Future Work
  • References

Then write one bullet point under each header. That’s your first outline.

Expand your outline gradually, turning bullet points into sentences and sections. Don’t worry about perfection—focus on getting your ideas down first.

docs.title: Researcher’s Compass
docs.text:
You don’t need to be an expert writer to publish your first paper. You just need to:

Writing is a process of discovery. As you draft and revise, you’ll clarify your thinking and strengthen your arguments. Be patient with yourself and trust the process.

  • Understand the structure
  • Write clearly and honestly
  • Revise with feedback
  • Follow the formatting rules

And most importantly: Start writing before you feel ready. Research doesn’t become real until you’ve put it on the page.

Every published paper started as a rough draft. The sooner you begin, the sooner you’ll see your research take shape.

docs.title: Chapter 14: Understanding the Peer Review Process
docs.text: “You’re not just writing for yourself—you’re writing for reviewers. And knowing how they think can help you succeed.”

docs.title: Why This Chapter Matters
docs.text:
Submitting your first research paper is exciting—but what happens after you hit “Submit” can feel like a black box.

Understanding the peer review process will help you set realistic expectations and respond constructively to feedback. It’s a rite of passage for every researcher, and learning how to navigate it will make you a stronger writer and collaborator.

Suddenly your paper enters the peer review process: - Who reads it? - What are they looking for? - How do you deal with feedback—especially if it’s harsh or conflicting?

This chapter explains what really happens during peer review and how to respond like a professional, even when your paper is rejected or criticized.

You’ll also learn how to use reviewer comments to improve your work and how to approach revisions with confidence.

docs.title: Conceptual Breakdown
docs.text:
🔹 What is Peer Review?

Peer review is the academic quality control system.

It’s designed to ensure that only high-quality, original, and significant research is published. Reviewers are usually volunteers—experienced researchers who want to maintain the standards of their field.

Your paper is evaluated by experts in the field—usually anonymous—who judge:

  • Originality: Is this a novel contribution?
  • Significance: Does this matter to the community?
  • Soundness: Are the methods valid and well-executed?
  • Clarity: Is the paper readable and well-structured?

Their feedback decides whether your paper is accepted, revised, or rejected.

Don’t be discouraged by critical feedback. Even the best papers are often rejected or require major revisions on the first try.

🔹 Types of Review Processes

Type Description Single-blind Reviewers know who the authors are, but authors don’t know the reviewers Double-blind Neither authors nor reviewers know each other’s identities (most common) Open review Reviewer names and reviews may be published (less common in CS)

Double-blind review is intended to reduce bias and ensure a fair evaluation. Always check your target venue’s guidelines for anonymization requirements.

✅ Always follow the submission rules—remove author names, affiliations, and citations to your own work if required by a blind review.

Failure to anonymize your submission can result in desk rejection before review even begins.

🔹 What Reviewers Usually Provide

You’ll usually get:

The tone and detail of reviews can vary widely. Some reviewers provide extensive feedback, while others are brief. Take all comments seriously, but focus on those that are actionable and supported by evidence.

  • A score (e.g., Accept, Weak Reject, Strong Reject)
  • A summary of what they liked and didn’t
  • Comments on:
  • Novelty
  • Clarity
  • Technical soundness
  • Comparison to related work
  • Suggestions for improvement

🎯 Pro Tip: If multiple reviewers mention the same weakness—it’s real. Fix it.

Use reviewer comments as a checklist for your next revision, even if you decide to submit elsewhere.

🔹 How to Handle Reviewer Feedback

Whether your paper is accepted, rejected, or asked to revise:

Remember, criticism is about the work—not about you. Most reviewers want to help you improve your paper, not discourage you.

  1. Stay calm. Don’t take it personally.
  2. Read all reviews fully. Let them sit before reacting.
  3. Highlight constructive points. These are gold for revision.
  4. Look for consensus. If multiple reviewers say the same thing, it’s a priority.
  5. Discuss with your advisor or mentor. Don’t revise alone if this is your first round.

Keep a record of the feedback and your responses. This will help you track improvements and prepare for future submissions.

🔹 Writing a Rebuttal (If Applicable)

Some conferences allow a rebuttal phase—a short document where you clarify or respond to reviewer comments.

The rebuttal is your chance to address misunderstandings and defend your work. Be concise, factual, and respectful. Avoid emotional language or personal attacks.

Tips:

  • Be polite, even if the review was wrong or unfair
  • Correct misunderstandings with evidence
  • Don’t argue emotionally—use facts and citations
  • Thank the reviewer for helpful feedback

Example phrase: “We appreciate Reviewer 2’s concern about X. We clarify that our dataset does include [condition], as mentioned in Section 3.”

Always thank reviewers for their time and suggestions, even if you disagree with their assessment.

🔹 Common Reviewer Comments (and What They Mean)

Reviewer Says... What They Might Mean “Paper lacks novelty.” You need to clarify what’s new in your work “Writing is unclear.” Revise for structure, grammar, and clarity “Insufficient comparison to prior work.” Expand your Related Work section “Results are not significant.” Add baselines or new evaluation metrics

Use these comments to anticipate and address weaknesses in your draft before submission.

✅ Use these as a checklist for revision—before you submit anywhere.

Ask a peer to review your paper and provide feedback using these common criteria.

docs.title: Self-Check Questions
docs.text:
1. Do you understand the type of review used by your target conference?
  2. Have you read sample reviews from past conferences or journals?
  3. Are you prepared to revise—even if you disagree with some feedback?

Reflect on your answers and discuss them with your advisor. Being prepared for feedback will make the process less stressful and more productive.

docs.title: Try This Exercise
docs.text:
Simulate a Review Pick a paper you’ve read recently (not your own). Pretend you’re the reviewer.

Write: - A short summary of the paper’s goal - 2 strengths - 2 weaknesses - A score (e.g., Accept / Weak Reject / Strong Reject) - One question you’d ask the author

This exercise will help you see your own writing from a reviewer’s perspective and improve your ability to anticipate and address criticism.

This builds empathy for how reviewers think—and helps you write with them in mind.

docs.title: Researcher’s Compass
docs.text:
Peer review isn’t perfect—but it’s how academic communities stay rigorous.

Every review, even a negative one, is an opportunity to learn and grow as a researcher. Over time, you’ll become more comfortable with the process and better at using feedback to strengthen your work.

Don’t see feedback as failure. See it as:

  • A mirror: showing where your ideas were misunderstood
  • A mentor: pushing you to be clearer, tighter, and stronger
  • A milestone: every review, even a rejection, is a step forward in your journey

Write with humility. Revise with professionalism. Grow with every round.

Remember, persistence and openness to feedback are key to long-term success in research.

docs.title: Chapter 15: From Draft to Submission
docs.text: “A research paper isn’t finished when it’s written. It’s finished when it’s submitted—carefully, ethically, and on time.”

docs.title: Why This Chapter Matters
docs.text:
You’ve written your paper. You’ve revised based on feedback. Now comes the final stretch—turning your draft into a professional, submission-ready manuscript.

This stage is about more than just uploading a file. It’s about attention to detail, teamwork, and making sure your work is presented in the best possible light. The final steps can be stressful, but with good planning and organization, you’ll avoid last-minute panic and increase your chances of a smooth submission.

But there are still decisions to make:

  • Who are the official authors?
  • How do you prepare your paper for the submission portal?
  • What deadlines matter most?
  • What happens after you hit submit?

This chapter guides you through the final mile of your research paper journey—with a focus on deadlines, ethics, formatting, and future steps.

You’ll also learn how to communicate with co-authors, handle submission systems, and prepare for what happens after you hit “submit.”

docs.title: Conceptual Breakdown
docs.text:
🔹 Set Internal Deadlines (Not Just the Final One)

Don’t aim for just the conference or journal deadline. Plan backwards.

Internal deadlines help you pace your work and ensure there’s time for feedback and revisions. Share your timeline with co-authors and advisors so everyone is on the same page.

Task Recommended Deadline Before Submission Finish first full draft 3–4 weeks before deadline Advisor or co-author review 2–3 weeks before deadline Final polishing (figures, format) 1 week before deadline Portal submission and checklist 2–3 days before deadline

✅ Always leave buffer time for technical issues (PDF errors, login problems, last-minute edits).

Unexpected issues are common—plan for them so you’re not caught off guard.

🔹 Author Order and Contribution Statements

Who gets listed as authors—and in what order?

Discuss authorship early in the process to avoid misunderstandings. Different fields and labs have different norms, so clarify expectations with your advisor and collaborators.

General principles:

  • First author = primary contributor (you, in most thesis cases)
  • Second/third/etc. = collaborators, mentors, or supporting researchers
  • Last author = often the senior advisor or lab head (in research groups)

Some venues now require a contribution statement, e.g., using the CRediT taxonomy:

Role Examples Conceptualization Who came up with the research idea? Methodology Who designed the system or experiment? Writing Who wrote the draft? Revised it? Supervision Who advised, reviewed, or mentored?

⚖️ Be transparent. Ask your advisor about authorship norms in your department or lab.

Contribution statements are becoming standard in many venues. They help clarify who did what and ensure everyone gets appropriate credit.

🔹 Submission Portals: What to Expect

Common platforms:

Each portal has its quirks. Familiarize yourself with the system before the deadline—some require account creation or specific file formats.

  • EasyChair – used by many CS conferences
  • PCS (Precision Conference System) – used by SIGCHI, SIGCSE, etc.
  • Editorial Manager / ScholarOne – used by journals

What you’ll usually need:

  • Title, abstract, keywords
  • Full author list and affiliations
  • PDF upload (sometimes ZIP with source files)
  • Conflict of interest declarations
  • Topics or areas for reviewer matching
  • Ethics/disclosure checklist

📌 Always double-check: Does your PDF compile correctly? Is it blinded, if required?

Check the submission guidelines for file size limits, naming conventions, and required forms. Incomplete or incorrectly formatted submissions can be desk-rejected.

🔹 What Happens After Submission

You’ll usually receive:

Keep all confirmation emails and submission receipts. They’re your proof of submission and may be needed if there are technical issues.

  • A confirmation email
  • A timeline for reviews and decisions
  • Sometimes: the option to edit metadata before the deadline

Then comes:

  1. Under Review – wait period (1–3 months typical for conferences)
  2. Decision Email – Accept / Minor Revision / Major Revision / Reject
  3. (Optional) Rebuttal Phase – respond to reviewer comments
  4. Camera-Ready Submission – if accepted, submit final formatted version

💡 Keep all files (source code, images, LaTeX, datasets) organized—camera-ready edits are usually under tight time constraints.

Consider using version control (e.g., Git) or cloud storage to keep your files safe and accessible to all co-authors.

docs.title: Self-Check Questions
docs.text:
1. Do you have a project timeline leading to your submission deadline?
  2. Have you clarified author order and individual contributions?
  3. Do you know what submission system your target venue uses?
  4. Have you created a checklist of formatting, anonymization (if required), and ethics declarations?

Review these questions with your team before the final submission. A little preparation goes a long way.

docs.title: Try This Exercise
docs.text:
Final Submission Checklist Builder Open a checklist doc and add:

  • [ ] Paper complies with formatting/template
  • [ ] PDF compiles with no errors or warnings
  • [ ] Author list is correct and verified
  • [ ] All references are accurate and cited
  • [ ] Ethics, funding, and disclosure forms (if required)
  • [ ] Submission portal account created
  • [ ] Backup copy stored in cloud drive

Add any venue-specific requirements to your checklist. Check off each item as you go to avoid missing critical steps.

You’ll thank yourself during deadline week.

docs.title: Researcher’s Compass
docs.text:
Finishing the writing is only half the finish line. A successful submission means you’ve:

The submission process is a test of your organization and professionalism. Treat it as seriously as the writing itself.

  • Followed ethical practices
  • Respected your co-authors and collaborators
  • Met the technical requirements
  • Managed your timeline like a professional

Every submission, whether accepted or rejected, brings you closer to your goals. Submit with confidence—and start preparing for what comes next.

Celebrate your submission—you’ve reached a major milestone. Then, take a breath and get ready for the next stage of your research journey.

docs.title: Chapter 2: Types of CS Research Topics
docs.text: “Not all research is built the same. Some prove theorems, some build systems, some ask questions no one thought to ask.”

docs.title: Why This Chapter Matters
docs.text:
Computer Science is not a single discipline—it’s a constellation of subfields, each with its own values, methods, and outputs.

As you begin to explore research, it’s easy to feel overwhelmed by the sheer variety of topics and approaches. Some students gravitate toward coding and building, while others are drawn to abstract puzzles or real-world impact. Understanding the landscape early helps you make informed choices and avoid frustration. The more you know about the different types of research, the better you can align your work with your strengths and passions.

Some researchers build software or hardware systems. Others write mathematical proofs. Some conduct user studies; others train deep learning models. All of them are doing “research,” but what they do day-to-day is vastly different.

This chapter will help you map the landscape of CS research categories so you can ask: What kind of builder do I want to be?

Understanding these research types early will save you from wasted time chasing projects that don’t fit your interests, skills, or goals.

docs.title: Conceptual Breakdown
docs.text:
🔹 Systems vs. Theory vs. Empirical Research

At a high level, CS research can be grouped into three big families:

Let’s look closer at what these families mean in practice:

  • Systems research is hands-on and creative. You might design a new database, build a robotics platform, or develop a novel networking protocol. The work is often collaborative, involving teams and iterative testing. Success is measured by whether your system works, scales, and solves real problems.

  • Theory research is about deep thinking and abstraction. You’ll spend time with mathematical proofs, logic, and complexity. The work is solitary at times, but also involves lively debates and peer review. Success is measured by the elegance and rigor of your results, and their impact on how we understand computation.

  • Empirical research is investigative. You’ll design experiments, collect data, and analyze results. This could mean running user studies, benchmarking algorithms, or evaluating new technologies in the field. Success is measured by the quality of your evidence and the insights you uncover about real-world behavior.

Type What It Focuses On Common Output Systems Building working software/hardware Frameworks, tools, protocols, datasets Theory Proving things mathematically Lemmas, theorems, complexity classes Empirical Testing and observing real-world behavior Experiments, user studies, evaluations

Each has a different culture of proof, writing, and publication.

For example, a systems paper might include code and performance benchmarks, while a theory paper focuses on definitions and proofs. Empirical work often features charts, statistics, and discussion of limitations. Learning to recognize these cultures will help you read papers more effectively and communicate your own work.

🔹 Applied vs. Fundamental vs. Exploratory

This is another lens to examine your direction:

These categories are not rigid boxes. Many projects blend applied, fundamental, and exploratory elements. For instance, you might start with an exploratory idea, develop a fundamental understanding, and then apply it to solve a real problem. The key is to notice which questions excite you most—do you want to build, understand, or discover?

Type Key Question Example Topic Applied “How can we use this to solve X?” Using AI to predict floods Fundamental “What are the limits or properties of Y?” Proving limits of cryptographic hash Exploratory “What happens if we try Z?” Visualizing large language model errors

You can mix and match. Some applied work has theoretical backing. Some exploratory work becomes the seed of a new applied method.

🔹 Quantitative vs. Qualitative Methods

CS isn't only about numbers.

  • Quantitative research includes benchmarks, metrics, statistical tests, ML model performance, etc.

  • Qualitative research includes interviews, thematic analysis, user feedback, open coding, etc.

HCI (Human-Computer Interaction), ICT4D (Tech for Development), and EdTech often use both.

Choosing your method depends on your research question. If you want to measure how fast an algorithm runs, you’ll use quantitative methods. If you want to understand how people feel about a new technology, qualitative methods are essential. Many impactful projects combine both, using numbers to show what’s happening and stories to explain why.

Don’t assume “real research” only means code and math. If your research deals with people, policy, or perception—qualitative work is not just valid, it’s critical.

🔹 Social Good and Interdisciplinary Research

Some of the most impactful CS work lies at the intersection of disciplines:

  • AI + Law → Legal tech, case triage, transparency bots
  • CS + Agriculture → Smart irrigation, drone surveillance, soil health analysis
  • CS + Education → Intelligent tutors, learning analytics
  • CS + Government → Budget bots, policy dashboards, fraud detection

These projects often:

  • Use applied methods
  • Require collaboration with domain experts
  • Involve both technical and human/systemic thinking

Interdisciplinary research is challenging but rewarding. You’ll need to learn the language of other fields, build relationships, and adapt your methods. The payoff is the chance to make a real difference in society. If you’re passionate about a cause—education, justice, health—consider how CS can amplify your impact.

This is where you come in. Your domain interests (education, justice, media, health, etc.) can drive the tech you build.

docs.title: Self-Check Questions
docs.text:
1. Do you enjoy building and debugging systems? (You may lean toward Systems research.)

  2. Do you love math, proofs, and abstract thinking? (You might be drawn to Theory.)

  3. Do you prefer testing, analyzing, and validating behaviors or ideas? (Empirical work may suit you.)

  4. Do you care about solving real-world problems or building tools for people? (Consider applied and interdisciplinary research.)

  5. Do you see your research as a way to serve a community or cause? (Look into social good and policy-related research.)

Reflect on your answers and consider discussing them with a mentor or peer. Sometimes, talking through your interests helps clarify your direction. Remember, your preferences may change as you gain experience—stay open to new possibilities.

docs.title: Try This Exercise
docs.text:
Mapping Your Curiosity: Make a 3-column table: - Column A: Fields you’re curious about (e.g., AI, CV, Networks, HCI, NLP) - Column B: Related real-world problems (e.g., access to justice, misinformation, disaster response) - Column C: Sample research types (system design, theoretical analysis, ML benchmarking, etc.)

You don’t need to pick one yet—just start seeing patterns.

As you fill out your table, look for connections between fields and problems. Are there areas where your interests overlap? Do certain research types appeal to you more than others? This exercise is meant to spark ideas and help you visualize your options.

docs.title: Researcher’s Compass
docs.text:
Choosing a topic is only half the question. The other half is: What kind of work are you excited to do every day?

Some researchers build. Others analyze. Some test. Some prove. You don’t need to do it all.

The best research is the kind that keeps you engaged and motivated. Pay attention to what energizes you—whether it’s coding, writing, experimenting, or collaborating. Your compass is your curiosity. Let it guide you toward projects that feel meaningful and sustainable.

Remember, the journey of research is as important as the destination. Stay curious, keep exploring, and don’t be afraid to change course as you learn more about yourself and the field.

Find your mode of inquiry—the method that makes you feel curious, engaged, and capable—and you’ll be more likely to finish what you start.

docs.title: Chapter 3: How to Settle on a Thesis Topic
docs.text: “A good thesis topic isn’t just interesting. It’s feasible, relevant, and meaningful—to the field, and to you.”

docs.title: Why This Chapter Matters
docs.text:
Many students believe choosing a thesis topic is about finding a “cool idea.” But in reality, the best topics are often born from constraints—your time, tools, interests, goals, and the world you’re trying to impact.

It’s easy to get caught up in the excitement of new technologies or trending fields. But the reality is that every research project faces limits—deadlines, available data, institutional support, and your own energy. The most successful theses are those that work within these boundaries, turning constraints into creative opportunities. By understanding what’s possible, you can avoid frustration and set yourself up for a rewarding experience.

This chapter will help you move from a vague interest to a concrete, researchable topic. We’ll break down how to balance feasibility, relevance, and personal alignment—so you can choose a direction that’s both doable and worth doing.

docs.title: Conceptual Breakdown
docs.text:
🔹 Feasibility: Time, Tools, Cost, and Scope

Before you fall in love with an idea, check its constraints:

  • Time: Can you realistically finish within 6–12 months?
  • Tools: Do you have access to the datasets, frameworks, or equipment?
  • Cost: Are there expensive licenses, APIs, or hardware requirements?
  • Scope: Can the work be broken down into milestones with measurable progress?

Feasibility is the foundation of any good thesis. Even the most exciting idea can become overwhelming if it’s too ambitious. Break your project into phases—literature review, data collection, prototyping, analysis, writing—and estimate how long each will take. Talk to your advisor or peers about what’s realistic. Remember, a well-scoped project is more likely to succeed and less likely to burn you out.

✍️ Tip: If your idea requires a drone or quantum GPU and you don’t have one, it’s not feasible—yet.

🔹 Relevance: Impact to Field, Society, or Country

Your topic should matter—somehow. That doesn’t mean it has to be groundbreaking. But it should:

  • Advance understanding in your field
  • Solve a real problem or inefficiency
  • Contribute to your community, institution, or country
